column1: Trieste lies in the northernmost part of the high Adriatic in northeastern Italy
column2: near the border with Slovenia. The city lies on the Gulf of Trieste.

column1: Built mostly on a hillside that becomes a mountain
column2: Trieste's urban territory lies at the foot of an imposing escarpment that comes down abruptly from the Karst Plateau towards the sea. The karst landforms close to the city reach an elevation of 458 metres (1
column3: 503 feet) above sea level.

column1: The territory of Trieste is composed of several different climate zones depending on the distance from the sea and elevation. The average temperatures (1971/2000) are 5.7 °C (42 °F) in January and 24.1 °C (75 °F) in July. The climatic setting of the city is humid subtropical climate (Cfa according to Köppen climate classification). On average
column2: humidity levels are pleasantly low (~65%)
column3: while only two months (January & February) receive slightly less than 60 mm (2 in) of precipitation.

column1: Trieste along with the Istrian peninsula has evenly distributed rainfall above 1
column2: 000 mm (39 in) in total; it is noteworthy that no true summer drought occurs. Snow occurs on average 0–2 days per year. Temperatures are very mild—lows below zero are somewhat rare and highs above 30 °C (86 °F) aren't as common as in other parts of Italy. Winter maxima are lower than in typical Mediterranean zone (~ 5–11 °C) but with quite high minima (~2–8 °C). Two basic weather patterns interchange—sunny
column3: sometimes windy but often very cold days frequently connected to an occurrence of northeast wind called Bora as well as rainy days with temperatures about 6 to 11 °C (43 to 52 °F). Summer is very warm with maxima about 28 °C (82 °F) and lows above 20 °C (68 °F)
column4: with the hot nights being influenced by the warm sea water. The absolute maximum of the last 30 years is 38.0 °C (100 °F) in 2003
column5: whereas the absolute minimum is −7.9 °C (18 °F) in 1996.

column1: The Trieste area is divided into 8a–10a zones according to USDA hardiness zoning; Villa Opicina (320 to 420 MSL) with 8a in upper suburban area down to 10a in especially shielded and windproof valleys close to the Adriatic sea.
The climate can be severely affected by the Bora
column2: a very dry and usually cool north-to-northeast katabatic wind that can last for some days and reach speeds of up to 140 km/h (87 mph) on the piers of the port
column3: thus sometimes bringing subzero temperatures to the entire city.

column2: Trieste became a maritime trade rival to the Republic of Venice which briefly occupied it in 1283–87
column3: before coming under the patronage of the Patriarchate of Aquileia. After it committed a perceived offence against Venice
column4: the Venetian State declared war against Trieste in July 1368 and by November had occupied the city. Venice intended to keep the city and began rebuilding its defenses
column5: but was forced to leave in 1372. By the Peace of Turin in 1381
column6: Venice renounced its claim to Trieste and the leading citizens of Trieste petitioned Leopold III of Habsburg
column7: Duke of Austria
column8: to make Trieste part of his domains. The agreement of voluntary submission (dedizione) was signed at the castle of Graz on 30 September 1382.The city maintained a high degree of autonomy under the Habsburgs
column9: but was increasingly losing ground as a trade hub
column10: both to Venice and to Ragusa. In 1463
column11: a number of Istrian communities petitioned Venice to attack Trieste. Trieste was saved from utter ruin by the intervention of Pope Pius II who had previously been bishop of Trieste. However
column12: Venice limited Trieste's territory to three miles (4.8 kilometres) outside the city. Trieste would be assaulted again in 1468–1469 by Holy Roman Emperor Frederick III. His sack of the city is remembered as the "Destruction of Trieste." He then restored the city walls for the fourth time. Trieste was fortunate to be spared another sack in 1470 by the Ottomans who burned the village of Prosecco
column13: only about 5.3 miles (8.5 kilometres) from Trieste

column1: === Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste (1947–54) ===

column1: Trieste's maritime location and its former long term status as part of the Austrian and
column2: between 1867–1918
column3: Austro-Hungarian empires made the Port of Trieste the major commercial port for much of the landlocked areas of central Europe. In the 19th century
column4: a new port district known as the Porto Nuovo was built northeast to the city centre.There is significant commercial shipping to the container terminal
column5: steel works and oil terminal
column6: all located to the south of the city centre. After many years of stagnation
column7: a change in the leadership placed the port on a steady growth path
column8: recording a 40% increase in shipping traffic as of 2007.Today the port of Trieste is one of the largest Italian ports and next to Gioia Tauro the only deep water port in the central Mediterranean for seventh generation container ships.

column1: Trieste is served by the Trieste – Friuli Venezia Giulia Airport (IATA: TRS). The airport serves domestic and international destinations and is fully connected to the national railway and highway networks.
The Trieste Airport railway station links the passenger terminal directly to the Venice–Trieste railway thanks to a 425-meter long skybridge. A 16 platform bus terminal
